text: hi I'm al baker I'm the police bureau
chief for The New York Times police
headquarters Bureau here in lower
Manhattan on Thursday evening May 28 at
about 1030pm there was what appears to
be a friendly fire incident between an
off-duty police officer who was shot and
killed by on duty plain clothes
anti-crime cops in east harlem new york
on 120 fifth street between first and
second avenue the officer who was just
getting off duty was Omar Edwards he's a
25 year old man he lives in Brooklyn
he's been a cop for about two years the
officer who shot him is Andrew dunton
he's a cop for about four years the
police are investigating the
circumstances of the shooting and all
the procedures that the officers took
before and after it today the mood at
police headquarters is pretty heavy the
department brass is huddling in places
examining the ballistic evidence they've
gathered witnesses at the scene they
have about five of those they've
interviewed the officer who was driving
the car who didn't shoot his gun and the
sergeant who didn't shoot his gun
they're prohibited from interviewing the
officer who fired until the district
attorney who's also looking at it
reviews the evidence the reason for that
is they don't want to give the officer a
potential defense if he's compelled to
answer questions today we've learned
that the officer was a member of the
football team he police football team
which is preparing for a game on Sunday
against the fire department his
father-in-law is a 16-year veteran of
the police department who works in the
67th precinct in Brooklyn so it's a
family of law enforcers for officer
Edwards we don't know much about officer
dunton this was the first time he fired
his weapon in the line of duty he fired
six shots the medical examiner today
found that officer Edwards was hit three
times once in the left forearm once in
the chest on the left side or in the
chest area and once in the left in the
back which appears to be the fatal wound
today the mayor bloomberg said that the
circumstances are still being
investigated these are life and death
encounters that spill out in very quick
moments on a rain rainey street late at
night in the dark in a very quick
fashion
the District Attorney Robert Morgenthau
will of course review the evidence as
well many people who are viewing it
today including Reverend Al Sharpton are
viewing it through the prism of race so
it raises issues of training of
communication of race relations of the
pressures that police face today may
29th we have reporters blanketing the
story and trying to piece together every
every element of this story
you
